p:slide.p:title: What is mark-up?

ul.li: Annotations on a text
Distinct from the text itself in some way
Electronic texts are marked up using tags

p:slide.p:code: It is **very** important to mark up your text
p:slide.p: That ** above is mark-up — we read it as emphasis
A mark-up language is just a set of rules for how to apply mark-up to text.

p:slide.p:title: Types of mark-up
p:slide.p: We can divide mark-up into three categories:

ul.li: presentational
procedural
semantic

p:slide.p:title: Presentational Mark-up
p:slide.p:
Uses cues in the content to show the structure of the content
e.g. row of hyphens under a line to indicate a heading

p:slide.p:title: Procedural mark-up
p:slide.p:code: E<bold>E<underline>Procedural Mark-upE<underline>E<bold> Procedural Mark-up uses embedded codes to indicate document structure. For example, the title here has been marked with tags to indicate bold and underlined text.

ul.li: Uses markers in the content to indicate formatting to be interpreted by some software
Word processors use procedural mark-up

p:slide.p:title: Semantic mark-up

p:code.title: Descriptive or Semantic Mark-up
p:code.para: Semantic mark-up attempts to indicate the function of a piece of text using tags.
This example uses para and title tags to mark pieces of text with those roles.

p:slide.p: Uses tags to indicate the function or meaning of a piece of text or information

p:slide.p:title: What does that have to do with language?
p:slide.p: These groups of tags are known as tag-sets or languages.
They are languages because we can create grammars for them – artificial languages.
A procedural mark-up language is much like programming – make this bold – a semantic mark-up language indicates what sort of thing we are talking about without defining what it should look like.
EXtensible Mark-up Language is a set of rules for creating mark-up languages.

ul.li: XML is a descendant of SGML*
SGML comes from work done by Charles Goldfarb at IBM in the 1960s.
SGML was standardised in 1986.
Started as an attempt to create a web profile for SGML
SGML was seen as too complex for web use
The XML Working Group simplified the syntax of SGML
Started in 1996
Became a W3C recommendation in 1998
XML and SGML are specifications that describe how you write a mark-up language
They are meta-languages
All XML based languages have common features:
opening and closing tags using angle brackets (<tag>) with the closing tag indicated by a forward slash (</tag>) attributes within the tags (<tag attribute=’value’>)
strict rules on how to create well-formed xml
HTML (pre HTML 5) is an SGML language - defined using the SGML rules
HTML 5 is SGML-ish but it's neither SGML nor XML
XHTML was created in 1999 to supplant HTML — it failed

p:slide.p:title: What’s the difference between SGML, HTML and XML?

ul.li: XML is a limited subset of SGML
HTML is a language written to the SGML rules
XHTML is a variant of HTML using XML rules!
